destinations.name: Cairo
destinations.description: Egypt’s bustling capital blends millennia of history with vibrant modern life. From ancient mosques to world‑class museums, Cairo is a gateway to the country’s treasures.

destinations.name: Giza
attractions: Giza Plateau Sound and Light Show
destinations.description: Home to the iconic pyramids, Giza offers an unrivaled glimpse of ancient engineering. The site’s open‑air museums make it easily accessible for all visitors.

destinations.name: Alexandria
destinations.description: Mediterranean breezes and layered history define Egypt’s second city. Its waterfront sites and Greco‑Roman relics provide a relaxed cultural escape.

destinations.name: Luxor
destinations.description: Often called the world’s greatest open‑air museum, Luxor is a treasure trove of New Kingdom monuments. Its hot desert climate is offset by cool evenings along the Nile.

destinations.name: Aswan
destinations.description: Set on the Nile’s first cataract, Aswan offers dramatic scenery and Nubian culture. River cruises from here continue the classic Egyptian itinerary.

destinations.name: Hurghada
destinations.description: This Red Sea resort town is a hub for snorkeling, diving and beach relaxation. Its well‑developed tourist infrastructure makes travel easy for families and solo adventurers.

destinations.name: Sharm El Sheikh
destinations.description: World‑renowned for its crystal‑clear waters, Sharm is a premier diving destination. The town also offers vibrant nightlife and desert excursions.

destinations.name: Dahab
destinations.description: A laid‑back alternative to Sharm, Dahab attracts backpackers and divers alike. Its small‑town vibe and stunning reefs are best explored with a local guide.

destinations.name: Marsa Alam
destinations.description: Located on Egypt’s far‑south Red Sea coast, Marsa Alam offers pristine coral and turtle nesting sites. Its remote location guarantees uncrowded beaches.

destinations.name: El Gouna
destinations.description: A purpose‑built luxury resort, El Gouna blends modern architecture with natural lagoons. It is ideal for families seeking upscale amenities and water sports.

destinations.name: Soma Bay
destinations.description: A tranquil beachfront enclave, Soma Bay is famed for its luxury hotels and world‑class golf. The clear waters make it a hotspot for diving and kite‑surfing.

destinations.name: Ain Sokhna
destinations.description: Just a two‑hour drive from Cairo, Ain Sokhna is a quick escape to the Red Sea. Its well‑maintained resorts cater to weekend travelers.

destinations.name: Siwa Oasis
destinations.description: Remote and serene, Siwa preserves a unique Berber culture amid palm groves and salt flats. Guided tours are recommended due to its isolated location.

destinations.name: Bahariya Oasis
destinations.description: A gateway to Egypt’s spectacular desert landscapes, Bahariya offers surreal sand seas and ancient ruins. Travel by 4×4 with a local guide is advised.

destinations.name: Kharga Oasis
attractions: Sand Dunes of the Western Desert
destinations.description: The largest of Egypt’s western oases, Kharga blends archaeological sites with stark desert beauty. Its remote position calls for organized tours.

destinations.name: Dakhla Oasis
destinations.description: Dakhla’s palm‑filled valleys and ancient forts showcase a quiet side of Egyptian desert life. Visitors benefit from a local guide for navigation.

destinations.name: Saint Catherine
destinations.description: Nestled at the foot of Egypt’s highest peak, this area is steeped in biblical lore and Byzantine art. Trekking to the summit is best done with an experienced guide.

destinations.name: Nuweiba
destinations.description: A quieter stretch of the Sinai coast, Nuweiba is favored by wind‑surfers and camel trekkers. Its simple accommodations keep costs low.

destinations.name: Ras Sudr
attractions: Marine Reserve of the Red Sea
destinations.description: Located on the eastern Sinai coast, Ras Sudr offers uncrowded beaches and excellent water sports. The area is developing but still maintains a low‑key feel.

destinations.name: Suez
destinations.description: The gateway between the Mediterranean and Red Sea, Suez is a bustling port city with industrial heritage. Its museums explain the canal’s pivotal role in world trade.

destinations.name: Port Said
destinations.description: Founded during the canal’s construction, Port Said boasts European‑style architecture and vibrant markets. The city’s waterfront promenade offers scenic canal views.

destinations.name: Rosetta
destinations.description: Famed as the place where the Rosetta Stone was discovered, Rosetta blends historic sites with a quiet Nile setting. It is a pleasant day‑trip from Alexandria.

destinations.name: Ismailia
destinations.description: Nestled on the western bank of the Suez Canal, Ismailia offers lush gardens and a relaxed riverfront atmosphere. Its colonial heritage is evident in the architecture.

destinations.name: Tanta
destinations.description: The capital of the Nile Delta’s agricultural heartland, Tanta is known for its bustling markets and the Mosque of Ahmad al-Badawi.

destinations.name: Beni Suef
destinations.description: Located south of Cairo, Beni Suef serves as a gateway to the southern pyramids and Middle Egypt sites.

destinations.name: Minya
attractions: Old Coptic Church of St. George
destinations.description: Minya is a cultural crossroads where ancient Egyptian tombs meet Coptic heritage. Often called the 'Bride of Upper Egypt'.

destinations.name: Fayoum
destinations.description: Just a short drive from Cairo, Fayoum offers a mix of natural beauty and ancient sites like Wadi El-Hitan.

destinations.name: Mansoura
destinations.description: A bustling Nile Delta city, Mansoura blends commercial activity with historic architecture and is famous for its medical centers.

destinations.name: Zagazig
destinations.description: Serving as the capital of the Sharqia Governorate, Zagazig is a key agricultural hub near the ancient site of Bubastis.

destinations.name: Sohag
destinations.description: Sohag is a gateway to Upper Egypt’s monastic heritage, featuring remarkable Coptic monasteries.

destinations.name: Asyut
attractions: Monastery of the Virgin Mary at Qus
destinations.description: Situated on the bank of the Nile, Asyut is a historic trade centre and home to one of the largest universities in Egypt.

destinations.name: Qena
destinations.description: Qena lies close to the famed Dendera Temple and is known for its beautiful pottery and Islamic architecture.

destinations.name: Edfu
destinations.description: Home to Egypt’s best‑preserved Ptolemaic temple, Edfu offers a deep dive into ancient religious architecture.

destinations.name: Kom Ombo
destinations.description: The double‑temple of Kom Ombo honors the crocodile god Sobek and falcon god Horus.

destinations.name: Abu Simbel
destinations.description: Carved into a mountainside, the Abu Simbel temples are a world-famous engineering marvel.

destinations.name: Wadi El Hitan
destinations.description: A UNESCO World Heritage site, Wadi El‑Hitan preserves prehistoric whale fossils in a stunning desert landscape.

destinations.name: Marsa Matrouh
destinations.description: On the Mediterranean coast, Marsa Matrouh offers turquoise waters and soft white sands.

destinations.name: Al Alamein
destinations.description: Famous for WWII battles, Al Alamein now features luxury resorts and solemn war memorials.

destinations.name: Dendera
destinations.description: Dominated by an exquisitely preserved temple dedicated to the goddess Hathor.

destinations.name: Wadi El Natrun
destinations.description: The birthplace of Christian monasticism, home to four ancient and active Coptic monasteries.

destinations.name: Bilbeis
destinations.description: One of the oldest cities in Egypt, home to the first mosque built in Africa.

destinations.name: Abusir
destinations.description: An Old Kingdom necropolis featuring rare sun temples and unique pyramid structures.

destinations.name: Saqqara
destinations.description: Egypt's oldest and largest necropolis, showcasing the evolution of pyramid building.

destinations.name: Dahshur
destinations.description: A tranquil pyramid field featuring the Red Pyramid, the world's first successful smooth-sided pyramid.

destinations.name: Memphis
destinations.description: The first capital of United Egypt, now an open-air museum housing colossal statues.

destinations.name: Damietta
destinations.description: A port city where the Nile meets the sea, famous for its wood craftsmanship and furniture.

destinations.name: Tell el-Amarna
destinations.description: The short-lived capital of Pharaoh Akhenaten, dedicated to the sun disk Aten.

destinations.name: Abydos
destinations.description: One of the most sacred sites of ancient Egypt, center of the cult of Osiris.

destinations.name: Kharga
destinations.description: The capital of the New Valley, home to the beautifully preserved Temple of Hibis.

destinations.name: Dakhla
destinations.description: Famed for its mud-brick medieval village and lush date palm groves.
